import React from "react"; import './Content.css'; const Content = () => { return (

Content

  1. Group 1: Architectures for Microservices and Nanoservices
    • Alanezi & Mishra: Utilizing Microservices Architecture for Enhanced Service Sharing in IoT Edge Environments (Paper 1)
    • Zaki et al.: Cloud-Assisted Microservice-Based Framework for Healthcare Systems
    • Pallewatta et al.: Placement of Microservices-based IoT Applications in Fog Computing: A Taxonomy and Future Directions (Paper 10)

    Comprehension of lightweight service-oriented architectures in distributed systems requires a comprehension of the fundamental ideas of microservices and nanoservices, which are examined in this category. The chosen papers explore architectural frameworks that improve deployment and service sharing in IoT edge settings. For example, Alanezi and Mishra's work on the use of microservices architecture emphasizes how microservices can improve service delivery in situations with limited resources, highlighting the synergy between edge computing and the Internet of Things.

    The study by Zaki et al. also presents a cloud-assisted microservice-based framework for healthcare systems, demonstrating real-world microservices implementations in crucial industries. Pallewatta et al. provide a structured method for comprehending the placement difficulties in distributed environments by contributing a taxonomy for microservice deployment in fog computing. When taken as a whole, these papers offer a thorough understanding of the architecture, functionality, and importance of microservices and nanoservices in contemporary Internet of Things applications.

  2. Group 2: Edge and Cloud Deployment and Placement Strategies
    • Pallewatta et al.: Placement of Microservices-based IoT Applications in Fog Computing: A Taxonomy and Future Directions (Paper 10)
    • Taleb et al.: Energy- and Resource-Aware Graph-Based Microservices Placement in the Cloud-Fog-Edge Continuum (Paper 21)
    • Islam et al.: Resource-Aware Dynamic Service Deployment for Local IoT Edge Computing: Healthcare Use Case (Paper 15)

    In order to guarantee effective resource usage and performance optimization, our group focuses on microservices and nanoservices deployment methodologies across edge and cloud platforms. Several deployment models and placement algorithms that provide efficient distributed service management are highlighted in the papers selected for this category. Pallewatta et al.'s study, for instance, sheds light on the taxonomy and difficulties of microservice placement in fog computing, which is essential for maximizing service delivery in edge computing scenarios.

    Additionally, Taleb et al. address important issues in resource allocation throughout the cloud-fog-edge continuum using a unique graph-based method for placing microservices that are resource- and energy-aware. The dynamic service deployment study by Islam et al. demonstrates tactics designed specifically for healthcare applications, guaranteeing prompt service availability in emergency situations. When taken as a whole, these studies highlight the complexity of implementing microservices in a variety of settings and the necessity of flexible approaches that take into account the unique features of cloud and edge computing.

  3. Group 3: Cloud, Edge, and IoT Resource Management and Optimization
    • Harjula et al.: Edge Computing for Industrial IoT: Challenges and Solutions (Paper 9)
    • Gkonis et al.: A Survey on IoT-Edge Computing and Its Challenges (Paper 18)
    • S치nchez-Gallegos et al.: Research and Simulation of Service Delivery in the Industrial IoT (Paper 16)

    This group investigates various resource management and optimization techniques pertinent to cloud, edge, and IoT ecosystems. The chosen papers provide insightful perspectives on challenges and solutions in resource management and task optimization across distributed settings. For example, Harjula et al.'s paper on edge computing for industrial IoT highlights the various challenges faced in resource allocation, revealing practical solutions for effective service delivery.

    Gkonis et al.'s survey also discusses the challenges associated with IoT-edge computing, providing valuable insights into current resource management strategies. Meanwhile, S치nchez-Gallegos et al. present simulations that examine service delivery in the industrial IoT context, showcasing real-world implications of effective resource management and optimization. Collectively, these studies underscore the significance of resource optimization techniques in ensuring effective service delivery across diverse IoT and edge environments.

  4. Group 4: Service-Oriented Architectures' Scalability and Performance
    • Namasudra et al.: A Survey on Service-Oriented Architecture Scalability and Performance (Paper 11)
    • Gkonis et al.: A Survey on IoT-Edge Computing and Its Challenges (Paper 18)
    • Wen et al.: Performance Evaluation of Microservices in Edge Computing Environments (Paper 22)

    This group focuses on the scalability and performance issues associated with service-oriented architectures. The selected papers examine various factors that contribute to effective scalability and performance in distributed systems. For instance, Namasudra et al. provide a comprehensive survey on the scalability challenges faced by service-oriented architectures, presenting various approaches to tackle these challenges.

    Gkonis et al. contribute by discussing the performance implications of IoT-edge computing, emphasizing the need for effective strategies to ensure service delivery in diverse environments. Wen et al.'s study on performance evaluation of microservices in edge computing environments provides empirical insights into performance metrics, thereby furthering our understanding of the implications of service-oriented architectures on scalability and performance. Collectively, these studies underscore the necessity for ongoing research into scalability and performance in service-oriented systems.

  5. Group 5: Security and Privacy in Architectures of Microservices and Nanoservices
    • Dhasarathan et al.: Security and Privacy in Microservices: A Survey (Paper 13)
    • Chen et al.: Security Issues and Challenges in Microservices Architecture (Paper 14)
    • Xu et al.: Security Mechanisms in Microservices-Based Systems: A Survey (Paper 20)

    This group addresses critical security and privacy concerns in microservices and nanoservices architectures. The selected papers highlight various security mechanisms and challenges that arise in distributed service-oriented systems. Dhasarathan et al.'s survey provides an extensive overview of the security challenges associated with microservices, emphasizing the need for robust security strategies.

    Chen et al. delve into specific security issues in microservices architecture, outlining the vulnerabilities that may be exploited in these systems. Xu et al.'s survey contributes to our understanding of various security mechanisms that can be employed in microservices-based systems, thereby providing practical solutions to enhance the security of service-oriented architectures. Together, these studies emphasize the importance of addressing security and privacy challenges in the design and implementation of microservices and nanoservices.

  6. Group 6: IoT and Edge Computing Applications in Healthcare
    • Abdullayeva: Leveraging Edge Computing in Healthcare: Opportunities and Challenges (Paper 12)
    • S치nchez-Gallegos et al.: Research and Simulation of Service Delivery in the Industrial IoT (Paper 16)
    • Harjula et al.: Edge Computing for Industrial IoT: Challenges and Solutions (Paper 9)

    This group focuses on the application of IoT and edge computing in the healthcare domain. The selected papers provide insights into the various opportunities and challenges associated with implementing service-oriented architectures in healthcare applications. Abdullayeva's work emphasizes the potential of edge computing in enhancing healthcare service delivery while highlighting the challenges that need to be addressed for effective implementation.

    S치nchez-Gallegos et al. present simulations that explore service delivery in the context of industrial IoT, thereby offering valuable insights into healthcare applications. Harjula et al. address specific challenges faced in the industrial IoT setting, thereby contributing to our understanding of the complexities involved in applying IoT and edge computing in healthcare. Collectively, these studies underscore the transformative potential of IoT and edge computing in healthcare while also emphasizing the need for further research and development.

  7. Group 7: Research and Simulations in Theory
    • Kim et al.: Control Theory Applications in Microservices (Paper 19)
    • Harjula et al.: Edge Computing for Industrial IoT: Challenges and Solutions (Paper 9)
    • Taleb et al.: Energy- and Resource-Aware Graph-Based Microservices Placement in the Cloud-Fog-Edge Continuum (Paper 21)

    This group focuses on theoretical studies and simulations that advance our understanding of service-oriented architectures. The selected papers investigate various theoretical frameworks and applications relevant to microservices and nanoservices. Kim et al. explore control theory applications in microservices, presenting a novel approach to understanding service behavior in distributed systems.

    Harjula et al.'s work on edge computing for industrial IoT and Taleb et al.'s study on energy- and resource-aware placement strategies further contribute to the theoretical foundations of microservices. Together, these studies emphasize the importance of theoretical research in informing practical applications and addressing challenges associated with service-oriented architectures.
